p: All the tested EOs were characterized by the same “Intensity” and “Persistency” (F 2,28 = 2.030, p = 0.150 and F 2,28 = 0.063, p = 0.939, respectively), while the “Pleasantness” resulted as significantly different (F 2,28 = 3.958, p < 0.031) with F. vulgare Eos that showed the highest rank values and P. lentiscus EO showing the lowest ( Figure 1a). When added to wheat, the EOs showed a significant difference for the smell “Intensity” and “Persistency” (F 2,28 = 5.041, p = 0.013 and F 2,28 = 4.790, p = 0.016, respectively). The EO of F. vulgare resulted as less intense and persistent in comparison with the EO of P. lentiscus ( Figure 1b), while no significant differences were recorded for the smell “Pleasantness” (F 2,28 = 2.913, p < 0.071). In general, among the tested EOs, O. basilicum and F. vulgare EOs showed the best olfactory traits, both alone and in combination with wheat. Conversely, the smell profile of P. lentiscus EO was characterized by the presence of “Chemical” off-flavors, as indicated by panelists ( Table 2).
